PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND DESCRIPTION 3. Pro-ect Objectives. The project's primary objectives would be to: (a) introduce water resources planning by river basins across all uses of water; (b) improve agricultural productivity through modernization and completion of irrigation systems, upgraded water management and farmer participation; (c) assure sustainability of water infrastructure and the environment; and (d) improve institutional and technical capability for managing the state's water resources. 4. Proiect Description. The project would be a sector investment loan implemented over seven years and financing an agreed state-wide program to improve the productivity and sustainability of Tamil Nadu's irrigation sector, to introduce multi-sectoral water planning, to integrate farmers in irrigation management, and to strengthen the state's institutional and technical capacity in water development, management and planning. Project components are: (a) System Improvement and Farmer Turnover; (b) Scheme Crim1ttiJona; (c) Water Plannina. Environmental Manaaement and Research; {d) In;titutional UDaradina; and (e) land acauisition and economic rehabilitation.
 - 216 - Annex 13 Page 2 of 9 5. The investment program would be supported by a number of policy and institutional reforms including: actions consistent with the objectives under the recently formulated "Tamil Nadu State Water Policy"; the creation and strengthening of the state "Water Resources Organization"; implementation of an Environmental Action Plan; prioritization of state expenditures in the irrigation sector emphasizing maintenance and institutional strengthening as first priority, followed by the system improvement and farmer turnover program, followed by viable scheme completions, and last (and only as needed within Tamil Nadu's state water planning requirements, particularly for metropolitan needs), viable new investment; full programming and funding of maintenance; measures to rationalize water charges, review cost recovery annually and hand-over O&M responsibilities and funding of distributaries to established farmer councils; measures to introduce groundwater legislation and regulatory actions for groundwater pumping; and establishment of an institutional apparatus, improved procedures and implementation of individual land acquisition and economic rehabilitation action plans for persons affected under the project (Refer chapter II of main report and relevant Annexes). B. IMPLEMENTATION PLAN 6. Project Management and Implementation. The project would be implemented by Tamil Nadu's Water Resources Organization (WRO). Project management would be under the responsibility of the Engineer-in-Chief, WRO, under the overall guidance of the Secretary, WRO (PWD). The EIC would have overall responsibility for implementation and coordination of all activities, supported by CEs responsible for their respective management units: CE Plan Formulation, CE Design, Research and Construction, CE O&M, CE State Water Resources and Data Center, CE IWS and CE IMTI, plus, for field management, the four CE Basin Managers. The EIC's office would be supported by a joint CE, units for Administration, Program and Budgeting, Monitoring and Evaluation, and Project Officers for special assignments. WRO would also contain a Regulatory Directorate and a Land Acquisition and Economic Rehabilitation Office. Environmental cells would be in IWS and with the CE Plan Formulation, plus smaller environmental units at basin manager level. The institutional structure. orcaaniarams and position descriptions are at Annex 2. Implementation responsibilities are at Attachment 2 of this Annex. 7. For water planning (refer Annex 3) the Water Resources Control and Review Council (WRCRC), chaired by the Chief Minister and with Ministers PWD (WRO), Municipal Administration and Rural Development as Vice Chairmen, and including representation from all Government Departments associated with water use and quality, would be the highest state body for coordinating basin and state water planning and allocation across sectors. The IWS would be the Secretariat of the WRCRC and Nodal Agency for state water planning. For coordination of the Environmental Action Plan (refer Annex 7), the WRCRC would contain an Environmental Sub-Committee. Specific management and implementation details for the System Imnrovement and Farmer Turnover proaram are at Annex 4. The institutional and management arrangements for the Land Acauisition and Economic Rehabilitation program are at Annex 9. Management arrangements for the Water Resources Research Fund are at Annex 8.
 - 217 - Annex 13 Page 3 of 9 8. Training and Technical Assistance. The extensive reorganization and institutional strengthening to be undertaken under the project, and the major initiatives in the areas of water planning, farmer participation and turnover, systems improvement, environmental management and business skills such as management information systems and programming and budgeting, would require substantial training and technical assistance throughout the WRO. Training and consultancy needs have been prepared by WRO and the Bank for each management unit and are detailed in their respective cost tables at Annex 11. Each CE would be responsible for managing the specific training and consultancy relevant to his management unit, but would receive administrative support from a Training and Technical Assistance Officer in the EIC's office. Overall coordination and identification of training opportunities would be provided by the CE, IMTI. The EIC would provide general guidance and balance needs between WRO units. Training would focus on strengthening skills in all engineering areas including operations and maintenance, water planning, environmental management, design and construction, and supporting skill development associated with technologies or management techniques relatively new to WRO such as financial management skills, programming and budgeting, computerization, computer aided design, remote sensing and management information systems. For consultancies, in order that know-how is transferred to WRO staff, consultant assistance would be linked in all cases to staff training through association of staff with consultant assignments and interlinked formal training as practicable. National and international study tours, training courses and temporary assignments with experienced water agencies would also be used to provide first-hand exposure to new technologies and management techniques. 9. Consultancy arrangements would include small consultancies with individuals or firms as needed, but would be backstopped throughout the project period with one main consultancy contract comprising a "twinning arrangement" with an experienced consultancy group. All consultancy selection would follow Bank guidelines. The twinning arrangement would be with a consortium of several firms or specialist institutions, likely including one international firm and one domestic firm, plus other firms/institutes as may be considered appropriate in the offers by consortia and as may be accepted in final selection of the most qualified offer. The central skill areas for an acceptable consortium, seldom found in one firm or agency, would comprise all aspects of irrigation engineering, water planning and modelling, environmental management, and hands-on irrigation management, particularly in O&M, general and corporate management techniques, and beneficiary participation, plus capacity to provide or arrange training in all of the above areas. One of the firms or agencies of the consortium would be the lead partner and have overall responsibility for mobilizing the consultancy and training support required. The contract would provide a basic expertise and training input annually, including some core senior staff providing continuity of visits, and access to other specializations and training on an "as needed" basis, with flexibility retained and provided for in the consultancy budget of the contract. Selection would be through an initial invitation and subsequent prequalification of interested firms (in their prequalification offers the firms would advise of any intended partners), followed by short listing by WRO
 - 218 - Annex 13 Page 4 of 9 of about 4 (range 3 to 5) firms or groups of firms for submission of detailed offers. A contract over the full project period would be agreed at the outset, with flexibility for annual variations based on an annual review of consultancy and related training needs between WRO and the consortium in consultation with GOTN's Department of Finance and IDA. The above procedures would provide the expertise required while limiting constraints frequently found in India of obtaining individual clearances, especially for consultants and training requiring foreign exchange. Consultancy needs are contained in the detailed project cost tables by project component and WRO management units at Annex 11. 10. Additional to the above, WRO would: (i) contract a senior institutional advisor, institutional advisors and community organizers (NGOs) for the farmer participation and turnover program (already under implementation) (Annex 4); (ii) continue to hire the services of a national firm with expertise in land acquisition and economic rehabilitation for assisting the LAERO with the land acquisition and economic rehabilitation program over at least the first three years of the project; (iii) contract NGOs for implementation of the LAERAPs and administration of the associated RGF and AMG asset creation funds (Annex 9); (iv) contract a national fisheries specialist to advise on the fisheries component of the LAER program (Annex 9); contract a supervision consultancy contract to assist WRO and GOTN's "Supervision Committee" (para 17); (v) under advice of the Research Advisory Committee, contract Tamil Nadu, other Indian and overseas research institutes for the research and technology transfer program under the project's Water Resources Research Fund (Annex 8), and (vi) contract for other needs as may be determined by WRO and IDA during project implementation. 11. Staff Continuity and Specialization. WRO will ensure organizational and functional effectiveness by establishing various categories of specialists. These specialists will represent the broad range of responsibilities of WRO from design to maintenance to programming and budget. Specialists will be selected and provided additional training, either by IMTI or by outside training institutes or consultants. Study tours will also be arranged where appropriate to further enhance the expertise and awareness of technologies and management skills of the specialists. Consistent with the expenditure of time and funding to provide specialized training, posting policies will be modified to take advantage of this additional training by retaining these employees in their specialized disciplines. In many cases, transfers can still be accommodated but should be within the same discipline. In other cases the specialization is so specific and limited that few if more than one location will be able to utilize that speciality. For example, an earth dam designer can only be usefully posted with the Chief Engineer, Design, Research and Construction. In such instances the posting policy will allow an extended stay in the same location, with due consideration to the preferences of the employee. Promotions would actively favor employees staying in a post for more than three years and employees staying in a particular speciality. 12. Implementation Schedule. A Summary Implementation Schedule for the project is at Attachment 1. Details by project component are in their respective annexes.

The financing olan is at para 3.04. Disbursement arrangements are described at para 3.13 and a Disbursement Schedule is at Annex 12. Arrangements for retroactive financing, the special account and accounting and auditing are at paras 3.15 and 3.16. 14. Procurement Implementation and Schedule. Procurement arrangements are described at paras 3.05 to 3.12 of the main report. They include special management features (para 3.11) to ensure efficient and timely procurement. Detailed procurement schedules with contract packages, timing and estimated costs have been prepared for all field sites/components. An example of such a schedule is at Attachment 5 of this Annex. 15. Economic Analysis. The detailed economic analysis for the project is at Annex 14 and summarized with risk assessments and description of non- quantifiable benefits in chapter 5 of the main report. The overall economic rate of return for the project is estimated at 17%. Sensitivity tests and risks analysis are in Annex 14. C. MANAGEMENT AND SUPERVISION PLAN 16. Management and Supervision Tools. A project of this nature requires close management, monitoring and supervision for its success. Sustainable success depends on creating a management and monitoring structure and capability integral to the entirety of WRO's operations and continuous after the duration of the WRCP. For this reason, management information systems (MIS), monitoring and evaluation (M&E) capability, programming and budgeting (P&B), use of development indicators including the results of a baseline survey, and a system of quarterly reports and a closely followed Annual Review, Action Plan and Budget, supplemented by special reports on certain components and a mid-term review, have been integrated in project management. These will form the basic tools for management, supervision and actions to redress problem areas and exploit evolving opportunities for faster or modified implementation. They will in themselves significantly raise the management capabilities of WRO, which were constrained within the former PWD due to lack of basic management tools. PWD did not have, or had only in very limited form, capabilities in MIS, M&E and P&B. As important in terms of limiting the facility of management, PWD's organizational structure was overly centralized with inadequate delegation of authority. Further, management units were only partially organized around functional specializations limiting staff specialization which was further exacerbated by frequent staff transfers. The new organization (Annex 2) around functional specialties, divested of non-water related activities, and with decentralized control nearer to field sites, will - once fully established - greatly improve the task of management. It will enable WRO's evolution, associated with intensive training and consultancy assistance, to a modern water agency. The management tools above are described in the paragraphs below and relevant sections of the main report and its annexes.
 - 220 - Annex 13 Page 6 of 9 17. GOTN and GOI Supervision. In view of the institutional and technical challenges to be undertaken under the project, GOTN will implement special measures to provide additional supervision support from government. A WRCP Supervision Committee has been formed by GOTN chaired by the Secretary WRO with the Secretary, Finance Department as Vice Chairman and EIC, WRO as Secretary and including the Member (Irrigation) of the state Planning Commission, Land Development Commissioner, plus two experienced invited members (former WRO, other government department or business community/NGO with proven management ability). In central government, MOWR, DEA, Advisor (Irrigation) Planning Commission (and other ministries such as environment where issues addressed are relevant) will also be copied minutes and have standing invitations to attend as possible. As relevant for particular issues, other GOITN representatives will be invited to participate (eg Agriculture Department, AED, Environment, District Collectors). Meetings will be at least quarterly to discuss the quarterly reports and the ARAPB, and more often as needed. Additionally, a Supervision Consultancy will be arranged and funded under the WRCP with a national consultancy firm. This would provide backstopping consultancy assistance to the WRCP Supervision Committee and site visits. The consultants would make two visits per year, timed to overlap with IDA supervision missions, and additional assistance as needed. Consultant reports would be made to the committee and copied to IDA and GOI. 18. IDA Supervision. An indicative IDA Supervision Schedule is at Attachment 3, and would be adjusted as needed during project implementation. The overall plan comprises in a typical year two formal visits, supplemented by correspondence, clearances and visits of WRO staff to the Delhi office as needed. One of the visits would be short and primarily of an expediting nature: checking progress, helping resolve interim constraints, dealing with consultancy, procurement, disbursement and accounting matters arising. One main mission a year would be timed to coincide with the review of the draft ARAPB in the December/January period and would make selective visits to the field, go through all aspects of the project and help determine the forthcoming year's program and review the program budget. GOTN's "Supervision" consultants (para 17) would, inter alia, include in their program missions of their consultants at the same time as both the IDA visits. Visits of the core staff of the main consultancy contract would also be timed where possible to overlap with the IDA missions, and as needed, similar arrangements would be made for specialists, especially where decisions are required on particular aspects of the project. Special meetings of GOTN's "supervision Committee" (para 17) would be convened by GOTN at the time of the IDA visits for discussion with IDA staff. These arrangements would enable harnessing of the required specializations to enable effective multi- disciplinary supervision and close interaction between WRO and its consultants, GOTN and IDA, while keeping IDA resource requirements within reasonable dimensions. The IDA Supervision Plan at Attachment 3 also allows for: (i) more intensive supervision at project start-up, including in procurement and disbursement, institutional reorganization, for the systems improvement and farmer turnover program, for the LAER program and for basin planning; (ii) the interim review of the farmer turnover program in PY2; and (iii) the mid-term review in PY 3.
 - 221 - Annex 13 Page 7 of 9 19. Monitoring. Evaluation. Programming and BudQeting. With the emphasis of WRO on improving overall management of water resources in Tamil Nadu, there is a need to consolidate and report the activities of WRO in a format which will assist the EIC and the Government in assessing program progress and performance, and for programming and budgeting to maximize effectiveness. There will be two staff units, reporting directly to the EIC: the Monitoring and Evaluation Unit, and the Program Budgeting and Accounting Unit. Consultancy assistance will be used to guide the establishment and initial operation of both units, and as needed thereafter. 20. Monitoring and Evaluation. The new Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Unit is an independent entity which will: (i) monitor expenditures on programs relative to total estimated costs; (ii) conduct post-project evaluations to compare benefits with original planning estimates; and (iii) perform evaluations of organizational effectiveness and performance of units within WRO for compliance with the goals and objectives of WRO. The M&E Unit would utilize the program budgeting process for much of its data to evaluate progress of projects and programs. At the request of any organizational unit or as directed by the EIC, the M&E unit would collect data, conduct site visits, initiate discussions with water users and the public, and evaluate reports to determine any deficiencies or problems and provide a report to the requestor with recommendations for action. 21. The Monitoring and Evaluation unit will also monitor and evaluate development effects on crop yields, total crop production, crop diversification, farm income levels, water distribution efficiencies and project affected persons. The current situation will be assessed based on personal visits, discussions with water users, sample surveys, questionnaires, and review of official publications. The evaluation will determine these effects by comparing the situation of a given time with the Baseline Survey (Annex 10). Annual reports will be prepared for dissemination to the State, Government of India, the World Bank, universities and others. Also, the unit will assess the effectiveness of the Farmer Organization and turnover Program and its impact on water delivery efficiencies and other factors. The unit will utilize the services of consultants or local or other universities for special surveys and analyses, as appropriate. The development effects could be used in the future to assist the Government in setting agricultural production targets by matching crop water demands with available water supplies by region or command. 22. Program. Budgeting and Accounting. WRO's new Program Budgeting and Accounting Unit (PBA) will establish, maintain, and administer the program budget and accounting system. The system will be used to develop annual budgets by consolidating budget requests from all WRO organizational elements and ensure that the final budget request is consistent with the policies and instructions from the Government. The system will provide the mechanism for tracking program progress and to assist the EIC in making recommendations on transfer of funds from one program to another. the unit will provide periodic management reports for use by the EIC, CEs and other managers for decision- making purposes. In addition and to support all activities in WRO, the unit will develop and maintain a Management Information System (MIS).
 - 222 - Annex 13 Page 8 of 9 23. Development Indicators. Development Indicators (Attachment 4) corresponding to the project objectives at para 3 have been chosen to help track the project's impact on the project objectives. Attachment 4 provides a matrix of monitorable indicators against each project objective and comments on how such indicators may be monitored. Indicators include physical indicators for the field components and qualitative and progress indicators for other components. The indicators include: implementation of the institutional restructuring and strengthening and its effectiveness, agricultural growth, productivity and crop diversification, increased delivery of water and improved services, implementation and effectiveness of the farmer participation and turnover program, and improved planning, programming and budgeting. 24. Baseline Survey. To provide a basis for monitoring the development impact of the project, and further refining the development indicators above, a baseline survey to be conducted by consultants would be carried out in 1995 (TOR for the Baseline Survey is at Annex 10). The survey would comprise an overall survey supplemented by more detailed surveys at the level of sample commands, and remote sensing for assessment of effective irrigation coverage and cropping patterns, and would cover the following aspects: engineering indicators for operational and maintenance performance; agricultural production indicators; performance indicators for the institutional restructuring and strengthening; and indicators for the farmer participation and turnover program. 25. Ouarterly Revorts. The quarterly reports would be issued within two weeks of the end of each quarter and would be issued by the Programming and Budget unit after clearance from the EIC. Each quarterly report would contain a listing of standard tracking data on physical progress, financing, procurement and disbursement, a sub-set of relevant qualitative data from the baseline survey determined parameters, brief submissions from each implementation unit in WRO which would quantify and compare progress with the SAR and the previous ARAPB and highlight problems, constraints and recommended solutions, and an overview section from the EIC's office summarizing decisions or recommendations based on the overview and each management unit's submission. This would include commentary on status of decisions/actions outstanding from the last quarterly report and review of any decisions/actions still required related to recommendations of the GOTN Supervision Committee, GOI or IDA. The reports would be presented to the Secretary WRO, and copied to the Minister, Supervision Committee and relevant state officials, GOI and IDA. Proforma guidance for the report is in the project file, with a single component example at Attachment 6. The Supervision Committee would meet to discuss and act/advise after each quarterly report, and IDA would provide advice by written or mission communication. 26. Annual Review. Action Plan and Budaet (ARAPB). The ARAPB would be the main vehicle for annually taking stock of project performance and future needs, for adjusting WRO's program as needed, for budgeting by GOTN of WRO's Plan and Non-Plan expenditures, and for annual major review and supervision by GOTN, GOI and IDA. For WRO it would provide annual opportunity to assess its
 - 223 - Annex 13 Page 9 of 9 program, to propose adjustments as needed, and to make its consolidated plan and justification for financing needs for the forthcoming year. The ARAPB would review for each _omponent and responsible unit the past year's achievements in terms of development indicators, physical targets and expenditures, and propose a justified work program and yroposed expenditure budaet for the forthcoming fiscal year. It would also include: (i) description of each year's works, schedule of activities, staffing requirements and distribution of responsibilities; (ii) proposed next year expenditures compared witlh previous full year's expenditures and budgeted and expected expenditures in current year; (iii) details on major civil works contracts exceeding US$ 200,000 and for ICB for goods; and (iv) financing plan and sources of funds. Special sectioons would cover: (v) review of implementation progress related to the institutional strengthening and policy reforms under the project; (vi) detailed review and proposal of maintenance needs (command-by-command) and corresponding non-Plan expenditure requirements; (vii) the farmer participation and turnover program; and (viii) progress of state water planning under WRCRC and IWS. 27. Interim Review of Farmer Organization and Turnover Program. This would enable feedback and recommendations sufficiently early in project implementation to enable timely adjustments. 28. Mid-Term Review.  - 239 - Anntex 14 Page 1 of 11 TAMIL NADU WATER RESOURCES CONSOLTDATION PRO.TECT Economic Analysis 1. OveXview: The Tamil Nadu Water Resources Consolidation Project would assist Tamil Nadu State to significantly refocus its program in the water and irrigation sector. The State's water resources agency would be modernized, and complemented with supporting policy and institutional mechanisms to plan and manage water from a multi-sectoral and environmentally-responsive perspective. The project would introduce mechanisms for private sector participation in water management activities, including the turnover of irrigation facility operations and maintenance to farmer organizations. Irrigation sector expenditure priorities would be revised to ensure first priority to full funding of maintenance activities, second priority to rehabilitation and modernization of existing irrigation schemes, and third priority to completion of existing schemes. In addition, the project introduces to the water resources agency the use of rigorous criteria for future project selection. These actions together would serve to improve the productivity and sustainability of irrigation services and ensure the timely provision of water to all user. 2. Besides the irrigation benefits, the project would also generate long-term benefits which are more difficult to quantify. Transforming the irrigation branch of the Public Works Department (PWD) from a construction-oriented agency into a specialized Water Resource Organization (WRO) would improve the management of the State's water resources to include a multi-sector and environmentally- sustainable perspective. Groundwater protection would be enhanced by improving groundwater monitoring, regulations and enforcement. Allocation of water resources between agricultural and non-agricultural users would be improved through more holistic water planning. Bulk water supplies for industrial and domestic users would be assured by multi-use basin and state water planning wherein they would enjoy high priority. Revision of irrigation sector expenditure priorities, in addition to improved project selection criteria, would yield efficiency gains for the State, allowing it to avoid costly and unnecessary projects and to invest in the most effective projects upfront. Lack of quantitative data prevents the explicit incorporation of these benefits in the analysis, but their significance is large. Analysis and Methodologfy 3. The analysis concentrates on quantifying the impact of project activities on irrigation and agricultural production. The non-quantifiable benefits will be described briefly though they will not figure into the determination of project viability. In concert with the project's structure which is comprised of two main components, the analysis is divided into two parts: first, the economic analysis for the scheme completions, then a separate analysis for the modernization and rehabilitation component of the project. This division is chosen because it provides better opportunities for monitoring project progress after implementation. 4. Water is a scarce good in Tamil Nadu. Domestic and industrial users compete with agriculture for water resources and demand will continue to increase. Project activities would increase the surface water supply availability for all sectors. Currently more than 90% of the surface water
 - 240 - Annex 14 Page 2 of 11 supplies are used in the agriculture sector, so most of the increases in surface water supplies through project activities are likely to be added to irrigation and rural water supply. The economic benefits of increasing surface water supplies through project activities could theoretically be calculated by using bulk water prices for industrial, domestic, or agricultural use. The current water rates in Tamil Nadu (industry Rs. 500/'000m3 , domestic Rs. 200/'000m3, agriculture Rs. 14-26/'000m3) belong to the highest in India. However, these prices are more an indication of political will than actual efficiency prices for bulk water and can therefore not be used for the analysis. To cautiously value the benefits of the project, the increase in surface water supplies is evaluated in terms of the marginal benefits of water supplied to irrigation which is generally the least attractive alternative. 5. Economic import and export parity prices are calculated based on the World Bank Revision of Primary Commodity Price Forecasts, July 1994 (Table 1) using year 2000 projections expressed in constant March 1994 prices. Export parity prices are used for cotton and sugarcane, import parity prices calculated for paddy and for fertilizer. Rice is treated as an import substitute as Indian demand and supply analysis for rice indicates the need for substantial expansion of domestic production to avoid imports. Although India is essentially self-sufficient in rice production, there will be a need to increase paddy productivity in order to keep pace with population growth and positive income effects due to economic growth. Sugar and cotton are valued at export parity prices. Groundnuts and coconuts are treated as non-tradeable since they are consumed as fresh products, and do not compare with internationally traded copra or vegetable oil commodities. The project's incremental production of these crops is fairly small and would be absorbable in the local fresh market. The financial prices, adjusted with a standard conversion factor (SCF) of 0.9, are comparable to export parity prices for copra and slightly higher for groundnut oil. All non-internationally-traded products have been adjusted with the standard conversion factor (SCF) for India of 0.9. The economic prices for seeds, labor, draught power, and machinery are based on financial prices, net of taxes, adjusted by the SCF. Scheme Completions 6. This component involves the construction works required to complete irrigation schemes which are currently being undertaken. From an earlier list of twenty candidate sub-projects, thirteen candidates were selected for detailed analysis during project preparation on the basis of preliminary screening, including assessment of water availability within Tamil Nadu's overall water planning and development objectives, and assessment of likely economic viability. Of the thirteen schemes, five have construction activities at a fairly advanced stage. Construction on the remaining eight candidates is either in the early stages or proposed to start, with land acquisition and tender procedures under preparation. On the basis of the analysis below, nine of the thirteen candidates have been selected for inclusion in the WRO's work program over the WRCP period. 7. While worldwide and Indian experience suggests that new irrigation schemes typically have low economic rates of return, higher rates of return can generally be expected from investments to complete the substantial backlog of on-going irrigation projects. However, ERRs above the opportunity cost of capital, even for scheme completions, are by no means automatic and the selection of candidates for finance has to be done rigorously based on economic, technical and social criteria.
 - 241 - Annex 14 Page 3 of 11 8. Benefits The Scheme Completions component has the direct objective of increasing the quantity of, and improving the reliability of water supplies for agricultural and domestic purposes. The direct benefits which would accrue as a result of the investments are as follows: 1. Increases in irrigated command areas; 2. Improved yields resulting purely from reduction in moisture stress; 3. Improved yields resulting from optimum input practices adopted by farmers in the light of improved reliability of water supply; 4. Agricultural intensification and changes in cropping patterns to higher value crops; and 5. Provision of domestic water supplies. 9. For each of the thirteen scheme completions appraised, the direct agricultural benefits have been quantified in detail and form the basis of the economic evaluation of the sub-component. However, secondary economic benefits (and costs) which could be available, but have not been valued and included in the analysis, would include: 1. Future options for bulk water supply to municipal and industrial users; 2. The net value of any fish production resulting from building reservoirs; 3. Improved drinking water supplies caused through groundwater recharge; 4. Any flood control due to the construction of civil works; 5. The byproduct values associated with the various crops to be grown; and 6. Social forestry schemes, and thus fuelwood output, planted in new tanks. 10. Crop budgets in economic terms have been derived from the financial crop budget and are set out in Table 2. These data were compiled from joint WRO and FAO/CP field visits to each scheme area. The value of the electricity consumed in supplementary irrigation from wells is extremely difficult to quantify because disaggregated records of power consumption are not available, and the use of well irrigation can vary significantly dependent on seasonal climatic conditions. Supplementary well irrigation would be reduced as a result of the project because groundwater and associated power consumption would be partly substituted by the increased and more reliable surface water supplies. For the purposes of the analysis, however, it is assumed that power consumption would not change with the project. 11. The investment costs in the economic analysis are derived from the detailed cost tables, adjusted to economic costs, and include physical contingencies. Annual operation and maintenance (O&M) costs have been estimated at Rs. 298/ha subsequently adjusted by the SCF, and applied from 1 April, 1994 onwards. This is based on a detailed estimate of requirement for full maintenance provided by WRO and reviewed during appraisal. These costs include current costs of staff.
 - 242 - Annex 14 Page 4 of 11 12. Methodology For each of the thirteen scheme completions, the economic rate of return was calculated to ascertain the economic viability of the scheme, and assess the merits for its financing. The economic rate of return calculation (ERR) is based on the following assumptions: (i) all costs are in constant March 1994 prices; (ii) project benefits and costs are calculated for 30 years; (iii) quantifiable net returns are from incremental crop production; (iv) O&M expenditures would remain constant over 30 years; and (v) the opportunity cost of capital is 12%. Thus, schemes are automatically included for financing if the ERR is at least 12%. 13. In order to estimate the incremental benefit and cost streams for each scheme, the irrigated areas were divided into areas defined by the source of irrigation water, which is set out graphically in Table 3. The future situation without the project is assumed to approximate the present situation without the project. For ongoing schemes, it has been assumed that all costs incurred before 1 April, 1994, will be treated as sunk. 14. In the base case scenario, scheme completions have been costed using standard Government construction rates, increased by 50%. The analysis also presents results using Government rates increased by 25%, and Government rates only. The use of Government rates plus 50% is based on analysis of actual past and present implementation experience, compared with unit rates quoted by the Government. This base case has been adopted for both the ERR analysis and project costing, given the importance of the economic success of each completion scheme in the overall program and adequate funding based on implementation experience. The costs further include physical contingencies of 10% for all civil works and vehicles, and 15% for all equipment. The approach taken during appraisal was to incorporate sufficient safeguards in the analysis and selection process of completion schemes to ensure as far as possible the economic viability of each scheme. 15. Results. The table below gives a summary of the economic rates of return and benefit/cost ratios for the thirteen candidate completion schemes, including sensitivity analysis for cost overruns. For details refer to Table 4. The results indicate that eight of the scheme completions, Adavinainarkoil, Gridhammal II, Kodumudiyar, Mordhana, Nambiyar, Poigayar, Rajathopekanar, and Vadakku Pachayar, are acceptable investment projects in economic terms since they would be expected to provide economic rates of return at or in excess of the opportunity cost of capital (OCC) for India of 12% p.a. Four schemes (shown at bottom of the table) are not viable and have been excluded from the project. 16. One scheme, Sothuparai, has an ERR of 11.2%, and under normal circumstances would not be considered for financing. A calculation of the switching value for benefits, however, indicates that benefits for Sothuparai would have to increase by only 6.5% for the ERR to be equal to 12%. This is equivalent to an additional NPV of Rs. 16 million (US$0.5 million), or Rs. 2 million (US$60,000) per year. The NPV of additional benefits amounts to an average of Rs. 9900/ha (US$300/ha), or Rs. 1200/ha per year (US$37/ha per year). These additional benefits would likely be achieved through the secondary benefits that would accrue as a result of the project, such as byproduct values from additional crop production (e.g. increased straw biomass for fodder), health benefits from improved drinking water, and new fisheries production. For example, it is estimated that net income from fisheries alone would be Rs. 14,000 (US$440) per fishing household per year (Annex 9, Attachment 5), which amounts to an estimated Rs. 1 million

On this basis, the Sothuparai scheme is considered an acceptable investment, and is included in the project package. Of the nine schemes above, six (Adavinainarkoil, Nambiyar, Poigayar, Rajathopekanar, Sothuparai and Vadakku Pachayar) have economic rates of return at or near the 12% level. The nine scheme completions together have an overall economic rate of return of 15% and a net present value of Rs. 338 million. The major benefits are an incremental production of 4,700 t of paddy, 5,500 t of groundnut and an additional 76,000 t of sugarcane (Table 5). 19. Systems Imorovement and Farmer Turnover (Modernization and Rehabilitation) 20. Background: The productivity of irrigation in Tamil Nadu is well below potential. On the majority of irrigation schemes, suboptimal distribution of water results in low yields and cropping intensity and reduced opportunities for diversifying agriculture. The existing infrastructure of the conveyance system has been deteriorating which further aggravates the suboptimal irrigation efficiency. The project's modernization, rehabilitation and farmer turnover activities are aimed at improving the productivity and efficiency of the irrigation system. Modernization and rehabilitation include activities like desilting of and repairs to the canals, repairs to structures, selected lining of canals and distributaries, on-farm development works, and improved operations management of the reservoirs and canals. Integral to the rehabilitation and modernization program will be a major thrust to hand over the responsibility of operation and maintenance below the distributary level to Water Users Associations. 21. Investments of this nature are generally considered to have high potential returns both in India and in other countries, and available analysis from a variety of sources confirms this (India, Irrigation Sector Review, Report No. 9518-IN). In Tamil Nadu, investments in modernization and rehabilitation are currently being financed under the National Water Management Project (NWMP) which commenced in the late eighties in seven of the State's schemes. First monitoring reports allow to tentatively assess the benefits in selected schemes. Although the monitoring process has not been completed because in most schemes the work is still ongoing, for two completed schemes, Sathanur and Cumbum Valley, WRO has reported impressive increases in both expansion of effectively irrigated area and in yield (increases in irrigated area of around 100%, and yield increases in the order of 13 - 80% for paddy and groundnut). Most of the other schemes show a positive development in expansion of irrigated area (Table 6). 22. In total more than 660,000 ha of cultural command area (CCA) would be rehabilitated and modernized under WRCP. This includes 17 major and medium (more than 2,000 ha per scheme) and 40 minor schemes. The major schemes are further divided into stage 1 and stage 2 works. Stage 1 includes the most immediate repairs to the major canal system and is limited to expenditures averaging Rs. 5,300 per hectare. Investments falling under stage 2 include lining of distributaries and on farm development works. Stage 2 investments are limited to expenditures of not more than Rs. 10,000 (avg. Rs. 7,900) per hectare. 23. Benefits: The major benefits to be expected for agriculture are: (i) increases in cultivable area receiving full and more reliable water supplies which allow farmers to increase production intensity, (ii) improved yields resulting from reducing moisture stress and by using higher inputs, and (iii) intensification and diversification of the cropping patterns to higher value crops. Benefits to the non-agricultural sectors comprise more reliable bulk
 - 245 - Annex 14 Page 7 of 11 water supplies to domestic and industrial users. Water saved by increasing the efficiency of irrigated agricultural production could also be passed on to the other sectors in the future. The economic analysis nevertheless evaluates increases in surface water supplies in terms of the marginal benefits of water supplied to irrigation. Benefits will thus tend to be under-estimated, as agricultural water usage usually has lower returns than for industry. 24. In nearly all schemes, the actually irrigated Cultural Command Area (CCA) is considerably smaller than the originally designed CCA. Moreover, not all of the actually irrigated CCA receive sufficient irrigation supplies to fully irrigate the crops according to crop water requirements. To give a realistic assessment of the situation in Tamil Nadu in the economic analysis, irrigation benefits will be divided into benefits resulting from increasing: i) The irrigated area at the tail-end, enabling farmers to switch from rainfed to irrigated crops (reducing the gap); and ii) Water deliveries to partially irrigated land, enabling the farmers to derive incremental irrigated production (stabilization); 25. Methodology: A detailed economic analysis has been prepared for 16 of the 17 major schemes covering a designed CCA of 530,000 ha or 80% of the total area under consideration. The analysis follows a disaggregated approach looking at the agricultural cropping patterns, crop budgets, input use and production for each of the 16 major schemes separately. For three of the schemes, information on the existing agricultural structure has been prepared in detail jointly by WRO and FAO/CP. These three were selected as being representative of the three major types of irrigation water supply - canal only, tank only and canal/tank systems. The other 13 major schemes have been analyzed using crop budgets provided by the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU). The results of the economic analysis are extrapolated to a medium scheme and the minor schemes which have not been separately analyzed because they are scattered all over the State. 26. A detailed analysis of the benefits of the three selected model schemes (Kodayar, Vaigai Old Ayacut, Lower Bhavani) was carried out by identifying presently unirrigated areas, or areas of unreliable irrigation, that would be made reliable irrigation areas as a result of the modernization/rehabilitation works. Details of the cropping pattern and crop budgets were obtained during joint WRO - FAO/CP field visits to each site (Table 7). The analysis of the model schemes serves to confirm the economic viability, based on data from WRO and TNAU, of the other thirteen modernization schemes. 27. The TNAU crop budgets (Table 8) summarize information on inputs, outputs and prices and are based on an annual monitoring procedure of farm performance in all districts of the State based on a stratified sampling procedure. This farm management data base is the only statewide statistical source using actual performance information for the 1992/93 farming season. The without project yields for the major crops on partially irrigated land are 3.2-5.9 t/ha for paddy, 1.2-1.3 t/ha for groundnut, and around 100 t/ha for sugarcane, based on observed present yields in each of the different schemes. The wide yield range for paddy reflects the differences in yield levels from scheme to scheme (Table 9). Cropping patterns are established for each scheme based on information provided by WRO (Table 10). At full development it is assumed that: (i) The cropping pattern does not change when farmers fully irrigate their previously only partially irrigated land. Even though a change
 - 246 - Annex 14 Page 8 of 11 to higher value crops could be expected, this aspect has not been included; (ii) Rainfed crops are grown on 50% of the non-irrigated land, the remainder being left fallow (the gap). This assumption is based on national statistics and field observations; (iii) Irrigation benefits in stage 1 schemes consist of both a reduction of the gap and a shift from partial to full irrigation. Irrigation benefits in stage 2 schemes only consist of an increase from partial to full irrigation. This division was selected to account for the previous investments under the NWMP in stage 2 schemes; (iv) In all schemes, about 30% of the presently irrigated CCA moves from partial to full irrigation. This estimate has been given by WRO engineers and can be described as cautious compared with the first monitoring results of NWMP; and iv) Yields, hired labor and fertilizer use increase by 10% with full irrigation as compared to partial irrigation. The yield increases are based on realistic estimates of TNAU economists. 28. The economic analysis for the SIFT component is based on realistic assumptions on the incremental irrigation benefits of the project. Especially, the division of the irrigation benefits into two groups, partial to full irrigation and gap to full irrigation gives a detailed and realistic assessment of the actual benefits. 29. esaults; Modernization and rehabilitation of the analyzed 16 major schemes would allow to increase irrigation from partial to full supplies on an area of 107,000 ha, and an additional 34,000 ha presently not receiving any water would receive irrigation. After project implementation, annual irrigation benefits would amount to Rs. 1,040 million at March 1994 prices. At full development total foodgrain production of paddy, and groundnut would increase by 170,000 t per year (Table 10). 30. The ERR calculation is based on the same economic assumptions as the scheme completions. The implementation period for most of the schemes is seven years and incremental benefits are phased in, beginning with year 4. Determination of construction costs is based on actual costing experience under NWMP which sets limits on rehabilitation and modernization costs per hectare. A similar approach has accordingly been used with the addition of 10% for physical contingencies on civil works and vehicles, and 15% for all equipment. The type of works necessary for modernization/rehabilitation does not require large amounts of civil works and earthworks, nor major civil works which are subject to considerable cost variations. Base cost for civil work average Rs. 5,300/ha for stage 1 and Rs. 7,900/ha for stage 2 investments. Project costs for this component consist of the direct investment costs for the schemes, the farmer turnover component, the Irrigation Management & Training Institute, operation and maintenance costs of irrigation facilities (budgeted at Rs. 265/ha), and costs for maintenance of equipment. 31. The overall ERR for this component is 19% and reflects the expected high returns from increasing efficiency of already existing schemes. The detailed analysis for Kodayar, Vaigai Old Ayacut, and Lower Bhavani gives an ERR of 38%, 40%, and 24%, respectively. The component is especially robust to cost overruns
 - 247 - Annex 14 Page 9 of 11 as the sensitivity analysis for this component reveals. Nevertheless, as with the scheme completions, construction costs should be monitored carefully. Summary Results of the Economic Analysis 32. The overall Economic Rate of Return (ERR) is based on the same economic assumptions as the individual ERR's for the above described components. The economic cash flows are presented in Table 11. Total quantified benefits only consist of irrigation benefits of which at full development 25% and 75% can be attributed to the scheme completions and modernization/rehabilitation components, respectively. 33. The overall ERR for the project is estimated at 17% and the net present value in March 1994 prices at Rs. 1,990 million. The overall ERR is calculated as the combined ERR for the project's two investment components, scheme completions and modernization/rehabilitation/farmer turnover, which together account for 84% of the project's base costs. Costs and benefits have not been included for the project's water planning and environmental action plan as well as institutional improvement expenditures not directly related to the two production components. The expected benefits of the iatter components are substantial but are difficult to quantify. If the costs for these items are included, but without ascribing benefits, the overall ERR of the total project would fall to 13%, and the net present value would be R3. 587 million. At full development the project would achieve an incremental foodgrain production of paddy and groundnuts of 180,000 t per year. Sensitivity and Risks Analysis 34. The table below presents the results of the sensitivity and risks analysis covering increases in costs, decreases in benefits, and the switching values in costs and benefits that would reduce cash flow to break even levels. For example if costs increased by 20% the ERR for the overall project would fall from 17% to 14%. As expected, the SIFT component has higher returns than the scheme completions component, which are reflected in both the base case and the various scenarios. The switching values illustrate that benefits would have to fall by 30% or costs to increase by 43% for the ERR to fall to 12%. It is, however, unlikely for implementation shortfalls of this magnitude to occur, for several reasons: (i) estimates of costs are realistic (the SIFT component uses actual costing experience of the NWMP and the scheme completion costs are based on actual experience with on-going contracts); (ii) estimation of benefits was similarly realistic and detailed, using actual farm performance information from a statewide farm performance database (SIFT) or data compiled from WRO-FAO/CP field visits (completions), and obtaining disaggregated estimates for subcomponents of the project components; (iii) GOTN has achieved successful piloting of the modernization and rehabilitation activities on a large scale (153,000 ha) under NWMP, on which the extension to the larger WRCP program is based; (iv) GOTN has demonstrated its commitment to the project's implementation and sustainability through successful institutional and fiscal reorganization; and (v) WRO has proven capability and successful experience in implementing the kind of physical activities called for in the project. 35. The table also includes results of risks analysis of three other scenarios, i.e. (i) reduced implementation and realization of benefits, (ii) inadequate maintenance beyond the project period, and (iii) shortfalls in the Systems Improvement and Farmer Turnover component, which investigate their impact on the economic rate of return.
 - 248 - Annex 14 Page 10 of 11 36. Reduced imDlementation and realization of benefits. While the risk of shortfalls in implementation has been reduced through a variety of monitoring and incentive mechanisms built into the project to help ensure this, it is instructive to investigate the consequences of a delay in the implementation process. Under this scenario, where it is assumed that benefits are lagged by 2 years, the ERR of the overall project would fall from 17% to 13%, the ERR of the SIFT component would fall from 19% to 15%, and the ERR of the scheme completions component would fall from 15% to 12%. 37. Inadequate maintenance beyond the project period. The table also tests for a scenario that would develop if the WRCP's objectives to sustain full maintenance (supported by improved cost recovery and farmer turnover) were not continued beyond the project period, i.e. a historically relevant non- sustainability scenario. This scenario is possible if funds for 0 & M fall short of expectations after the project implementation period, resulting in significantly reduced long term benefits. The sensitivity test therefore assumes a scenario of gradually decreasing benefits, where: (i) the incremental benefits of the modernization/rehabilitation component cannot be sustained after year 10 and progressively fall to zero in year 20 producing no incremental benefits thereafter, and (ii) the incremental net benefits of the scheme completions would drop from 100% in year 10 to 50% in year 30. Under these assumptions the ERR would fall from 17% to 13% and the NPV would fall from Rs. 1,990 million to Rs. 350 million. This test illustrates the importance and the high pay-off of full funding of adequate maintenance requirements, hence the attention paid to full funding and vigorous monitoring of maintenance under the WRCP. GOTN funding of maintenance was brought to full requirements in the April 1994 budget, and GOTN has spelled out in its Letter of Development Policy its intentions for sustained funding for maintenance functions. 38. Shortfalls in the Systems Improvement & Farmer Turnover component. The potential exists for less than satisfactory completion of the SIFT component. SIFT incorporates an innovative public-private partnership-that calls for new kinds of skills and markedly different attitudes on the part of both government personnel and farmers. In particular, management of farmer organizations are intended to be autonomous and must no longer be subjected to bureaucratic or political pressures. The inherent risk is that the bureaucracy may not easily undergo the necessary transformation and may continue to exert influence on farmer organizations. A scenario that tests for this possibility of incomplete implementation of SIFT assumes: (i) a 2 year lag in benefits, (ii) a 30% shortfall in benefits, and (iii) a 20% increase in costs. Under these assumptions the ERR would drop from 19% to 13% for SIFT and from i7% to 14% for the overall project. The NPV would fall from Rs. 1,652 million to Rs. 186 million for SIFT, and from Rs. 1,990 million to Rs. 524 million for the overall project.

 - 275 - Annex 15 Page 1 of 4 INDIA TAMIL NADU WATER RESOURCES CONSOLIDATION PROJECT Criteria For Preparation and Selection of Investment 1. Introduction. This annex deals with the criteria to be utilized by WRO in the preparation of future investment schemes that may be included in the WRO's work program within the seven-year implementation period of the WRCP. The WRCP investments are directed to rehabilitation and modernization of irrigation schemes and completion of civil works related to other schemes. The latter focus on improving the source of supply of water to existing traditional irrigation infrastructure. On the policy side, WRCP focusses on setting up and strengthening of institutions dealing with irrigation and improving the water resource utilization planning capabilities of GOTN. As discussed in other sections of the SAR, Tamil Nadu is a water deficit state with most of the current utilization of surface and ground water being in the agriculture sector. With the growth in the industrial sector and the need to provide the population with clean drinking water at a higher per capita consumption rate, competing demands on this limited resource will increase. Future schemes to meet these requirements in other sectors would involve transfer of water from agricultural use. In order to meet and maintain agricultural water requirements, additional schemes similar to those supported under this WRCP may be required. These needs may indeed arise over the next seven-year period as better basin plans are prepared and water utilization projects are identified and executed in other sectors. As a case in point, GOTN is currently preparing a water supply project to be implemented by TWAD Board' to provide potable water to the city of Madras which might involve transfer of water from agricultural use to municipal use. In the future, WRO would be responsible for providing bulk water supplies to municipal and industrial sectors2. There are also other schemes in planning stages similar to the nine scheme completions supported under this WRCP. in order to allow for investment assistance from IDA for such developments, an unidentified category has been established under the scheme completions component. Approval by IDA and the inclusion of any such future schemes under the WRCP would be dependant upon their satisfying the set of criteria outlined below. 1/ Tamil Nadu Water Supply and Drainage Board. 2/ These schemes would deliver untreated water at bulk rates to the municipal or industrial unit and therefore would involve only the development of a source be it surface water or subsurface water or both. Agencies such as TWAD Board and METROWATER will continue their role in urban water supply and drainage.
 - 276 - Annex 15 Page 2 of 4 2. Preparation and Selection Criteria. These criteria include the essential requirements that the schemes are: (a) prepared in the context of a river basin development considering all water use needs; (b) well prepared from all engineering, agricultural and other technical perspectives; (c) economically viable; (d) in full compliance with environmental and social requirements; and (e) identified and prepared in full consultation with beneficiaries. The criteria for investment scheme preparation and selection are: I. Basin Plan: The scheme should be prepared in the context of a river basin plan taking into account probable competing demands on the water source to be developed; it should fit in an overall riverbasin or subbasin development plan prepared by WRO. II. Water Demand: Estimates of water demands should be prepared taking into account the economic life of the proposed scheme. In the case of municipal and industrial sectors such estimates would be provided to the WRO by the responsible entities. WRO should ensure that these estimates cover a projected service period and specify the degree of reliability required. In the case of irrigation schemes, crop water requirements should be prepared on the basis of climatic data using standard methodology3 taking into account the contribution of effective rainfall. In estimating these demands, soils and land suitability for potential crops to be grown under the scheme should be established based on data obtained from the agricultural department and future crops, cropping patterns and crop calendars should be established in consultation with farmer and agricultural department officials. III. Water Availability: Detailed hydrological studies and reservoir yield analysis using standard methodology for supplies at the degree required. Quality of water supplied from the scheme must meet prevalent standards for raw water supply to municipalities or water boards, industries and agriculture as appropriate. In the case of groundwater exploitation4 , analysis of aquifer capacity, dynamic recharge potential for various probabilities, drawdown rates, pump capacities, availability of power to operate the prime movers and cost of such power should be estimated. In the case of irrigation schemes, wells in the scheme command must be identified and studied to establish conjunctive use which must be reflected in water balance computations. Analysis of existing irrigation infrastructure to clearly identify possible measures such as improving existing storages through dredging and improving 3/ Modified Penman-Monteith method is currently used by FAOCP to estimate potential evapotranspiration rates. 4/ This possibility is included for any such future eventuality. None of the appraised WRCP investments involves investment in groundwater explotation.
 - 277 - Annex 15 Page 3 of 4 efficiency of delivery systems should be prepared and the necessity to build new storages should be clearly established. IV. Engineering: Detailed engineering designs and implementation schedules, based on WRO capability and optimal contract packages, should be prepared. V. Operation and Maintenance Plan: Detailed 0 & M plan for the scheme should be prepared clearly spelling out the role of the end user in these and the financial and technical inputs required on a recurrent basis with an indication of how these requirements would be met. VI. Environmental Assessment: Necessary environmental impact studies should be prepared and mitigating measures if required should be identified and an action plan to implement such measures prepared. If the scheme involves building dams higher that 10m, designs would have to be presented to State DSRP and their concurrence obtained. Riparian rights should be assessed as well as impact on downstream users. In the event of a downstream user being affected, a counterimpact scheme should be prepared or suitable remedial measures be identified and included in the development of the scheme. VII. Resettlement and Rehabilitation: Detailed action plan for the economic rehabilitaion of scheme-affected persons should be prepared together with an implementation schedule and costed. Baseline socioeconomic surveys should be conducted to assist in this process. In the preparation of above, both reservoir area and pipeline or other delivery mechanism route should be included. Land acquisition and economic rehabilitaion plans together with realistic schedules for such acquisition and economic rehabilitation should be prepared. VIII. Costs and Benefits: Detailed costs for the engineering works should be prepared taking into account prevailing contract rates and optimal contract packages. The total costs should include LAER costs arising from the environmental impact assessment. Annual recurrent costs based on the 0 & M plan should also be included. In the case of irrigation schemes an estimate of annual net agricultural benefits should be made taking into account existing agricultural support services and an analysis of the markets for the agricultural produce .5 A detailed farming systems study should be carried out and the financial impact of the scheme on the beneficiary farmers be estimated. IX. Economic viability: Detailed economic analysis should be carried out using standard methodology (refer FAOCP reports for nine schemes). The economic rate of return should be 12% or greater. Social factors such as poverty alleviation, regional development etc., which could 5/ Unquanitified benefits (e.g. environmental, or health benefits from domestic water supply schemes) may also be documented, and where feasible, benefits ascribed.
