Cost Recovery: For bulk water supply schemes, establishment of cost of water for each scheme and agreement with the recipient on financial terms of supply. Legal agreement as needed should be prepared. For irrigation schemes, terms of cost recovery and farmer responsibilities should be agreed through memorandum of understanding.
 - 279 - Annex l Page 1 of 4 INDTA TAMIL NADU WATER RESOURCES CONSOLIDATION PROJTECT Maintenance. Water Charges and Cost Recovery 1. As a result of recent initiatives, Tamil Nadu has substantially improved its situation as regards funding of maintenance and actual and prospective cost recovery. Most important, GOTN is now fully funding maintenance expenditure needs. Second, water charges have been increased and now cover maintenance expenditure and the bulk of other recurrent costs. GOTN is also examining additional ways of improving water sector financing provisions and revenues, and the project would further assist in this process. 2. Maintenance Funding. In the past, Tamil Nadu has chronically underfunded irrigation maintenance, resulting in progressive deterioration of infrastructure. Recognising the need - pervasive in almost every Indian state - to substantially increase funding for maintenance works, GOTN has progressively increased its allocations for operations and maintenance over the last three years including an informal committment to IDA made in 1993 at the beginning of project preparation that maintenance funding would be at full required levels by project commencement and in all future years. From a funding level for operations and maintenance averaging only Rs 103/ha in 1989/90, GOTN increased O&M funding to Rs 120/ha in 1992/93, Rs 200/ha in 1993/94 and Rs 265/ha for the 1994/95 fiscal year. The 1994/95 allocation comprises a separate allocation to "maintenance works" (civil works, maintenance contracts and materials) of Rs 150/ha (the remaining Rs 115/ha being for staffing and other non-works recurrent costs). This follows the recommendations of PWD/WRO engineers and the Bank, and represents the full estimated requirement for maintenance works (94/95 prices) for the 1994/95 season. 3. An important detail in Tamil Nadu's Non-Plan funding provisions to WRO is that funding is disaggregated and earmarked. "Maintenance Works" have separate budget heads from establishment and other recurrent costs, and funds for "works" go into separate bank accounts, earmarked for works contracts and materials, with the relevant local branches of the State Bank of India. This desirable situation is being increasingly adopted by Indian states and will continue in Tamil Nadu. A common situation, applicable in Tamil Nadu also until recently, is that overall Non-Plan allocations are barely enough to cover staff salaries. As in such situations staff salaries have always had first call on funds, little has been left for actual maintenance. As staff salaries can be assumed payed, protecting the maintenance works budget is the critical need for sustaining water service infrastructure. The other needs are farmer pa-rticipation (non-breakages of structures, farmer turnover for the critical and most usually neglected lower levels of irrigation systems) and better planning, management and technical capability for O&M directorates of irrigation departments. 4. Water Charges. Tamil Nadu's water charges for irrigation are made up of a "basic irrigation rate', an "irrigation cess" which is calculated as a
 - 280 - Annex 16 Page 2 of 4 multiple of the basic rate and an "additional irrigation cess", also a multiple of the basic rate. The basic rate, and the resultant overall water charge through the cess multipliers, is calculated by crop, soil type and season and presently has over a hundred rates. Through adjustments of the cesses, GOTN has progressively increased charges for irrigation, the most recent adjustment being in 1991. The typical rate now amounts to between Rs 200-210/ha, amongst the highest water charges in India. The present water charges more than cover expenditure needs for maintenance works (Rs 150/ha in 1994/95), and cover about 80% of all recurrent expenditure costs of WRO including establishment (both staff employed on O&M and other staff). 5. GOTN has also applied a policy of freezing all recruitment to PWD, and envisages continuing this for WRO until staff numbers are balanced to work needs. This will bring establishment costs down further, and the farmer turnover program under the project will allow continued decline in O&M staff requirements as farmers assume greater responsibilities. 6. For commercial and industrial bulk supplies from WRO, rates have also been increased. From very low previous levels, both industrial and commercial, rates were increased in 1986, and then subjected to a further increase of eightfold in 1991: from Rs 60/1000 cubic meters to Rs 500/1000 c.m. A temporary court order injunction has since resulted in rates being brought down to Rs200/1000 c.m. This is still below service costs but is well above typical rates in other Indian states. Supplies for drinking water are supplied free of charge. Major drainage and flood protection works are also supplied free. 7. Further initiatives are expected from the work of GOTN's "Water Rates Rationalization Committee". This is examining agricultural rates. Based on the interim conclusions of the committee, likely recommendations will be a significant simplification of the present array of rates; from over 100 to less than 20. The committee is also examining ways of equitably increasing overall revenues. Final recommendations are expected in 1995. 8. The WRCP would further build on these initiatives. Full and timely provision of maintenance works funds by GOTN, a matter already agreed (and implemented for the 1994/95 year, see above) would be confirmed at negotiations and be the subject of a closely monitored assurance. "GOTN would: (a) provide annually to WRO the full funds required for maintenance to sustain the infrastructure in full operating order; (b) funds would continue to be allocated to a separate and protected maintenance works budget exempt from withdrawals for salaries and wages; (c) the maintenance works budget would be available from the beginning of the fiscal year so as not to impede maintenance activities; and (d) WRO would submit its annual budget estimate for maintenance to GOTN and IDA based on detailed command-by-command estimates following an agreed reporting, programming and budgeting and monitoring and evaluation process" (Annex 4). 9. on the revenues side, an important need is to have a permanent institutional apparatus for review of the costs of water services and the
 - 281 - Annex 16 Page 3 of 4 revenues received, and for annual review of status and possible adjustments. In Tamil Nadu's case, industrial, commercial and agricultural rates have all been the subject of recent increases, and intent for further change in agricultural rates is evidenced by the present work of the Water Rates Rationalization Committee. This, however, is not a permanent body and is restricted in mandate to agricultural rates. The fact of recent price changes and the work of the committee is nevertheless welcome relative to situations in many states where rates have not been changed for many years, in some cases for over a decade. While political constraints are present, an important contributing factor is the absence of any mechanism and responsible party to annually review and make recommendations on service costs and fees. As change is unpopular, there is little incentive for any party to propose adjustments, and understanding of the disaggregated costs and revenues of water service provision is also often incomplete. GOTN, thus intends to establish a permanent "Water Service Costs and Revenues Committee". This would be chaired by the Secretary, PWD/WRO with membership comprising Secretaries Finance, Revenues Department, Land Administration, Agriculture, Municipal Administration, TWAD, Metrowater and WRO's EIC and Basin Managers, and a co- opted Consultant economist. The consultant would, under the direction of the committee, prepare an annual status report covering the service costs (recurrent and taking account of capital recovery) of all water services (irrigation, drainage, flood control, rural drinking water, municipal, industrial and commercial), fees applied and revenues, with regional disaggregation as appropriate (for instance by basin/major water source and major urban centers), and disaggregated and overall net revenues-costs situation. The annual report and any recommendations forthcoming from the committee would be distributed annually for consideration by state authorities (Cabinet and Bureaucracy). WRCP funds would cover the costs of Tamil Nadu's consultant over the life of the project, and the costs of an additional short- term consultant employed in PY1 to help establish a computerised and updateable multi-sectoral model. 10. The WRCP's Systems Improvement and Farmer Turnover Program will offer an opportunity to further improve on the financial situation of service provision for agricultural use. Cost recovery for irrigation has been impeded India- wide by the frequently low quality of the service. Poor irrigation and lack of involvement of farmers in irrigation operational plans, water management decisions and management and maintenance of irrigation leaves a disaffected farming community, lack of a sense of "ownership" in the irrigation system and resistance to water charge increases, usually seen as a tax unrelated to irrigation and with no correspondence to service quality. 11. The WRCP's Systems Improvement and Farmer Turnover program will include the following actions impacting on service costs and revenues. On the investment side, for "On-Farm-Development", large savings will accrue from state withdrawal to the role of topographic survey and extension, with construction limited to provision of outlet and profile wall structures, and with farmers rather than WRO or AED now handling water channels, field channels and field drains. State investment costs at this level would come down from Rs 3500/ha to Rs 500/ha. For distributaries lining, investmet would
 - 282 - Annex 16 Page 4 of 4 now involve a 20% contribution from farmers. Lining has usually been the most expensive item under modernisation programs for the secondary distribution system, and has often been excessively applied, especially where groundwater recharge would be beneficial. By establishing farmer contributions for this item, generally less essential than the water control structures, cost savings would result both from the contributions from farmers and from reduction in the demand for lining, which will be substantially reduced to reaches where farmers consider it to have significant benefits. On the recurrent expenditure side, members of farmer councils would make an up-front contribution of Rs 250/ha to their bank account and would take over maintenance and operations of their distributaries under the Memorandum of Understanding established with WRO. This would reduce WRO's notional maintenance costs by about 30%, though its overall effect would be gradual in line with progress under the turnover program. 12. Measures beyond the above would also be considered by the Water Service Costs and Revenues Committee. First, a service fee increase (conceptually like a betterment levy) could be considered for stage II investments. Second, the current practice of all rural revenues being collected by the Revenues Department could adjust to collection by Farmer Councils. A limited objective could be for Farmer Councils being allowed to collect, still pass on to the Revenues Department, but retain a percentage as collection reward, with higher percentage retention against higher collection rates (actual collections divided by dues). A relatively easy adaptation would be for Farmer Councils to be charged volumetrically (measuring devices are part of the package for monitoring of water flows and the physical means would thus already be present). This is a highly likely evolution as experience is gained under the program. More fundamentally, GOTN should look towards going beyond internalising O&M costs and revenues at distributary levels to achieving the same objective at the levels of entire commands and at state level; ie progression towards a "utility" approach, with funds collected and used directly by the service provider. Funds could be collected by Councils, agreed proportions passed on to the command level Apex Committees, and proportions handed on to the WRO bank account for the command concerned, with part handed on to WRO overhead expenses, with revenue-sharing related to costs of each entity. As regards management of O&M, farmer responsibility reaching beyond the level of distributary head, and perhaps to whole command (below the headworks) is a possible evolution, particularly for medium commands where a tradition of farmer organization is already strong. An objective under the project will be to encourage and facilitate any such initiatives as opportunities are identified. It is expected that at least some commands would be ready for further initiatives within several years. In the immediate time frame, however, the key need is to strongly establish the system improvement and farmer turnover program and gain the confidence and satisfaction of the farmers. On this basis, larger steps such as the above would have a good foundation for their success.

Cauvery systwm is the major one that drains more than one third of the state. The area to the north of Cauvary basin is drained by the Palar, the Ponnaiyar and the Vollar rivers. The area to the south of the Cauvery basin is drained by the Vaigai, the Gundar, the Vaippar and Tambaraparani. The drainage over greater part of Tamil Nadu follows the pattern of branching of a tree. The total drainage area in the state is 1.30 lakh Sq.Km. of which Cauvery basin accounts for 0.4B7 lakh Sq.Km. followed by Ponnaiyar (0.12 lakh Sq.Km.) and Palar (0.10 Lakh Sq.Km.). Tamil Nadu is highly vulnerable to cyclonic depressions and flooding. The depressions and cyclones are frequent during the months of Octobwr, November and December (i.e., northeast monsoon) along the coast from Madras to Ramnad.  - 302 - Annex 18 Paae 1 of 1 INDIA TAMIL NADU WATER RESOURCES CONSOLIDATION PROJECT Criteria for the Selection of Non-Government Organizations (NGOs) The project would seek NGO participation in various activities related to farmer organizations and beneficiary participation in management, operation and maintenance of irrigation systems, and to land acquisition and economic rehabilitation of project affected persons. Tamil Nadu's Water Resources Organisation (WRO) would invite from interested NGOs detailed proposals for collaboration. WRO would be responsible for reviewing the proposals and agreeing on appropriate mechanisms to involve NGOs in the project. The selection of NGOs would be guided by the following criteria: (a) As part of legal requirements, the NGO should be a registered body under the relevant State Law. It should regularly maintain its accounting records and have properly audited annual statements of income and expenditure. (b) Since the program involves working primarily with small and marginal farmers, it is essential that the NGO has a proven track record in community development in the agrarian setting. To avoid creating any biases and misconceptions in the minds of the people, the NGO should be secular and non-political in the conduct of its field activities. (c) As the project requires NGO support for farmer organization activities over many sites, and for land acquisition and economic rehabilitation in seven completion sub-projects, NGO's should have adequate numbers of field level staff conversant with the local dialect and customs, and having a clear understanding of the socio-economic and political situation of the area or areas in which they will operate. They should also possess excellent communication skills and good rapport with the community so as to involve them in their own farmer organization or economic rehabilitation. (d) A prior understanding of the concept of Water Resources Consolidation Project and experience in areas relevant to the NGO's interest in project participation (for instance, in community development, farmer organization, and land acquisition and economic rehabilitation) would be desirable. Owing to the nature and extent of the physical coverage of the program, each selected NGO will be part of the community organisation or land acquisition and economic rehabilitation process. Hence, the NGO should be able to interact smoothly with, and be a part of, a team. (e) Finally, the NGO should have internal stability so as to assure long-term support to the project.

doc.repnme: India - Tamil Nadu Water Resources Consolidation Project
doc.abstracts: The Tamil Nadu Water Resources Consolidation Project will be a sector investment loan financing an agreed state-wide program to improve the productivity and sustainability of Tamil Nadu's irrigation sector, to introduce multi-sectoral water planning, to integrate farmers in irrigation management, and to strengthen the state's institutional and technical capacity in water development, management and planning, The project will be implemented over seven years. Project components will be: (a) system improvement and farmer turnover; (b) scheme completions; (c) water planning, environmental management and research; (d) institutional strengthening; and (e) land acquisition and economic rehabilitation.
